metadata.description: Staple Singaporean rice and noodle dishes, from fragrant rice to stir-fried noodles

recipes.name: Foochow Red Wine Mee Sua (福州红糟鸡面线)
recipes.description: A traditional Foochow (Fuzhou) dish beloved in Singapore, featuring chicken braised in homemade red glutinous rice wine and served with silky wheat vermicelli (mee sua). Popular for celebrations and confinement, this dish is prized for its warming, aromatic broth and tender chicken.
steps: Marinate chicken pieces with a splash of red wine and a pinch of salt for 30 minutes (optional).
Bring a pot of water to boil. Cook mee sua according to package instructions (usually 1-2 minutes). Drain and rinse with cold water to prevent sticking. Set aside.
Heat sesame oil in a large pot or wok. Add ginger and stir-fry until fragrant.
Add red yeast rice (if using) and chicken pieces. Stir-fry until chicken is lightly browned.
Pour in Foochow red wine and enough water to just cover the chicken. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer, covered, for 30-40 minutes until chicken is tender.
Season with salt and a pinch of sugar to taste. The broth should be aromatic, slightly sweet, and warming.
To serve, portion mee sua into bowls. Top with chicken and ladle over the hot red wine broth. Garnish with spring onions and cilantro.
tips: Homemade Foochow red wine and red yeast rice give the most authentic flavor, but store-bought versions are acceptable.
This dish is often served during Chinese New Year, birthdays, and for postpartum recovery (confinement).
If you can't find red yeast rice, you can omit it, but the color and aroma will be less intense.
Do not overcook mee sua or it will become mushy.
recipes.source: Adapted from What To Cook Today, NoobCook, and Singapore/Malaysia Foochow home cooks.
recipes.origin: Foochow (Fuzhou) Chinese community in Singapore and Malaysia; a celebratory and confinement dish.

recipes.name: Fen Ti (Glass Noodles with Minced Pork)
recipes.description: A comforting Chinese home-style dish in Singapore, featuring glass noodles (mung bean vermicelli) stir-fried with minced pork, mushrooms, and aromatics. Savory, silky, and satisfying.
steps: Heat oil in a wok. Sauté garlic until fragrant. Add minced pork and stir-fry until no longer pink.
Add mushrooms and carrot, stir-fry for 2 minutes.
Add glass noodles, soy sauces, oyster sauce, sugar, pepper, and water/stock. Toss well to combine and cook until noodles are soft and sauce is absorbed.
Garnish with spring onion and serve hot.
tips: Soak glass noodles in warm water until just soft, not mushy.
Add more water/stock if needed for a silkier texture.
Can add prawns or other vegetables for variety.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Chinese home cooks.
recipes.origin: Chinese community in Singapore; a home-style comfort dish also found at hawker stalls.

recipes.name: Pumpkin Rice (Nankua Fan)
recipes.description: A comforting Chinese home-style dish in Singapore, featuring rice cooked with pumpkin, dried shrimp, mushrooms, and aromatics. Savory, sweet, and hearty, it's a favorite at home and hawker stalls.
steps: Heat oil in a wok. Sauté garlic, shallots, dried shrimp, and mushrooms until fragrant.
Add pumpkin and rice, stir to coat with aromatics.
Add soy sauce, oyster sauce, pepper, and water/stock. Mix well and transfer to a rice cooker or pot.
Cook as you would regular rice. Once done, fluff and garnish with spring onion. Serve hot.
tips: Use Japanese or local pumpkin for best texture.
Add Chinese sausage or pork belly for a heartier version.
Leftovers can be pan-fried for a crispy bottom.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Chinese home cooks.
recipes.origin: Chinese community in Singapore; a home-style comfort dish also found at hawker stalls.

recipes.name: Yam Rice (Orh Nee Fan)
recipes.description: A hearty Teochew/Chinese rice dish in Singapore, featuring rice cooked with yam, dried shrimp, mushrooms, and aromatics. Savory, earthy, and perfect with braised duck or pork dishes.
steps: Heat oil in a wok. Sauté garlic, shallots, dried shrimp, and mushrooms until fragrant.
Add yam and rice, stir to coat with aromatics.
Add soy sauce, oyster sauce, pepper, and water/stock. Mix well and transfer to a rice cooker or pot.
Cook as you would regular rice. Once done, fluff and garnish with spring onion. Serve hot, ideally with braised duck.
tips: Use fresh yam (taro) for best texture.
Add pork belly or Chinese sausage for a richer version.
Leftovers can be pan-fried for a crispy bottom.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singaporean Chinese home cooks.
recipes.origin: Teochew and Chinese communities in Singapore; a classic pairing with braised duck.

recipes.name: Braised Ee Mien (E-Fu Noodles)
recipes.description: A classic banquet and hawker dish of braised E-Fu (Ee Mien) noodles, stir-fried with garlic chives, mushrooms, and a savory sauce. Soft, springy noodles with a rich umami flavor, often served at celebrations.
preparation: Soak mushrooms in boiling water until softened, then slice.
Blanch E-Fu noodles in boiling water for 2 minutes, separate, rinse under cold water, and drain.
Heat oil in wok, fry garlic until fragrant, add mushrooms, then chives, and 2 tbsp seasoning. Stir-fry briefly.
Add noodles and remaining seasoning. Stir-fry to coat and allow noodles to absorb sauce.
Finish with sesame oil and kecap manis. Serve with sliced green chili.
tips: For extra umami, add a pinch of dried solefish or anchovy powder. Can add shredded chicken or prawns for a more substantial dish.
recipes.source: https://theninjacook.weebly.com/culinary-adventures/braised-e-fu-noodles
steps: Soak mushrooms in boiling water until softened, then slice.
Blanch E-Fu noodles in boiling water for 2 minutes, separate, rinse under cold water, and drain.
Heat oil in wok, fry garlic until fragrant, add mushrooms, then chives, and 2 tbsp seasoning. Stir-fry briefly.
Add noodles and remaining seasoning. Stir-fry to coat and allow noodles to absorb sauce.
Finish with sesame oil and kecap manis. Serve with sliced green chili.

recipes.name: Sheng Mian (Crispy/Soft-Fried Noodles)
recipes.description: A Singaporean zi char classic: egg noodles fried until crispy or soft, topped with a savory gravy of seafood, pork, and vegetables. Known for its textural contrast and rich, silky sauce.
preparation: Blanch noodles, then pan-fry in 2 tbsp oil until golden and crisp (for crispy version) or just until lightly browned (for soft version). Set aside.
Heat remaining oil, fry garlic, then add pork, prawns, squid, mushrooms, carrot, and choy sum. Stir-fry until just cooked.
Add chicken stock, oyster sauce, soy sauce, and bring to a simmer.
Thicken with cornstarch slurry, season with pepper and sesame oil.
Pour gravy and toppings over noodles. Serve immediately.
tips: For extra wok hei, use a very hot wok. Can substitute seafood with chicken or omit for vegetarian version.
recipes.source: https://www.noobcook.com/sheng-mian/
steps: Blanch noodles, then pan-fry in 2 tbsp oil until golden and crisp (for crispy version) or just until lightly browned (for soft version). Set aside.
Heat remaining oil, fry garlic, then add pork, prawns, squid, mushrooms, carrot, and choy sum. Stir-fry until just cooked.
Add chicken stock, oyster sauce, soy sauce, and bring to a simmer.
Thicken with cornstarch slurry, season with pepper and sesame oil.
Pour gravy and toppings over noodles. Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Yangzhou Fried Rice (Yang Chow Chao Fan)
recipes.description: A beloved fried rice dish with origins in Yangzhou, China, but a staple at Singapore zi char stalls. Features fluffy rice, prawns, char siu, egg, and vegetables, all tossed with a hint of rice wine.
preparation: Heat oil in wok, fry shallots and garlic until fragrant.
Add prawns and char siu, stir-fry until prawns turn pink.
Push to side, add beaten eggs, scramble until just set.
Add rice, carrot, peas, and toss to combine.
Season with soy sauce, pepper, salt, and drizzle rice wine around the wok.
Stir-fry on high heat until rice is dry and fluffy. Finish with spring onion.
tips: Use day-old rice for best texture. Can substitute char siu with ham or omit for vegetarian version.
recipes.source: https://www.julieolive.co.uk/2023/05/09/traditional-yang-chow-yangzhou-fried-rice-%E6%89%AC%E5%B7%9E%E7%82%92%E9%A5%AD/
steps: Heat oil in wok, fry shallots and garlic until fragrant.
Add prawns and char siu, stir-fry until prawns turn pink.
Push to side, add beaten eggs, scramble until just set.
Add rice, carrot, peas, and toss to combine.
Season with soy sauce, pepper, salt, and drizzle rice wine around the wok.
Stir-fry on high heat until rice is dry and fluffy. Finish with spring onion.

recipes.name: XO Fish Head Bee Hoon
recipes.description: A luxurious Singaporean noodle soup featuring fried fish head or fillet, thick bee hoon (rice vermicelli), choy sum, tomatoes, and a milky, aromatic broth enriched with XO cognac.
preparation: Marinate fish with fish sauce, XO, sugar, and pepper. Set aside in fridge.
Blanch choy sum and set aside. Cook noodles per package instructions.
Coat fish in rice flour and cornstarch, deep-fry until golden and crispy. Set aside.
In a large pot, heat oil, fry ginger, garlic, and white part of green onion until fragrant.
Add chicken stock, evaporated milk, chicken/fish powder, fish sauce, sugar, and tomatoes. Bring to a boil.
To serve: Place noodles, choy sum, and tomatoes in bowl. Ladle hot broth over, top with fried fish, fried shallots, and a splash of XO. Serve immediately.
tips: For a lighter version, use boiled fish instead of fried. Adjust XO to taste or omit for non-alcoholic version.
recipes.source: https://whattocooktoday.com/xo-fish-bee-hoon-soup.html
steps: Marinate fish with fish sauce, XO, sugar, and pepper. Set aside in fridge.
Blanch choy sum and set aside. Cook noodles per package instructions.
Coat fish in rice flour and cornstarch, deep-fry until golden and crispy. Set aside.
In a large pot, heat oil, fry ginger, garlic, and white part of green onion until fragrant.
Add chicken stock, evaporated milk, chicken/fish powder, fish sauce, sugar, and tomatoes. Bring to a boil.
To serve: Place noodles, choy sum, and tomatoes in bowl. Ladle hot broth over, top with fried fish, fried shallots, and a splash of XO. Serve immediately.

ingredient_breakdown.ingredient: firm white fish fillet or head

recipes.name: Laksa
recipes.description: Spicy coconut curry noodle soup with prawns, fish cakes, and cockles.
steps: In a large pot, heat oil and fry laksa paste until fragrant.
Add lemongrass and galangal, cook for 2 minutes.
Add coconut milk and chicken stock, bring to boil.
Simmer for 30 minutes to develop flavors.
Cook rice vermicelli according to package instructions.
Add prawns and fish cakes to broth, cook for 3 minutes.
Add cockles if using, cook for 1 minute.
Divide noodles and bean sprouts among bowls.
Ladle hot broth over noodles.
Top with eggs and garnishes, serve with lime wedges.
tips: Use fresh coconut milk for best flavor.
Adjust spiciness by adding more or less laksa paste.
Don't overcook the seafood - it should be just done.
recipes.source: https://www.seriouseats.com/singapore-laksa-recipe
recipes.origin: Laksa is a Peranakan dish with Chinese and Malay roots, famous for its spicy coconut broth and rice noodles. It is a staple in Singaporean hawker centres and a symbol of the country's multicultural cuisine.

recipes.name: Katong Laksa
recipes.description: Famous Singaporean laksa with thick rice noodles, prawns, fish cake, and spicy coconut broth.
steps: Blanch rice vermicelli in boiling water, drain and set aside.
Heat oil in a pot, fry laksa paste until fragrant.
Add chicken stock and bring to a boil.
Add prawns and cook until pink, remove and set aside.
Add coconut milk and simmer for 5 minutes. Season with salt.
To serve, place noodles in a bowl, top with prawns, fish cake, bean sprouts, and egg.
Ladle hot laksa broth over and garnish with laksa leaves.
tips: Use fresh coconut milk for best flavor.
Adjust spiciness by adding more or less laksa paste.
Don't overcook the seafood - it should be just done.
recipes.source: https://ieatishootipost.sg/katong-laksa-recipe/
recipes.origin: Katong Laksa is a signature dish of the Katong area in Singapore, known for its short cut noodles and rich, spicy coconut broth.

recipes.name: Satay Bee Hoon
recipes.description: Rice vermicelli topped with a spicy peanut satay sauce, cuttlefish, cockles, and vegetables.
steps: Blend peanuts, chili, garlic, and shallots. Fry in oil until fragrant.
Add tamarind juice, sugar, and water. Simmer until thickened.
Blanch vermicelli and toppings. Arrange in bowl, pour satay sauce over.
tips: Use freshly roasted peanuts for best flavor.
Adjust chili to taste.
recipes.source: https://www.noobcook.com/satay-bee-hoon/
recipes.origin: Satay Bee Hoon is a unique Singaporean hawker dish combining Chinese rice noodles with Malay-style satay sauce.

recipes.name: Singapore Prawn Noodles (Hae Mee)
recipes.description: A beloved Singaporean hawker noodle soup featuring a rich, aromatic prawn and pork broth, yellow noodles, prawns, pork slices, bean sprouts, and fried shallots. Served with spicy sambal and lime.

main.prawns: 500g, peeled and deveined (shells reserved for broth)

preparation: Peel and devein prawns, reserving heads and shells. Set prawns aside.
In a large pot, heat a little oil and fry prawn heads and shells until fragrant and red. Add garlic and peppercorns, fry briefly.
Add water and pork ribs. Bring to a boil, skim scum, then simmer 1 hour. Add rock sugar and season with salt to taste.
Blanch prawns, fish cake, and kang kong in boiling water. Blanch yellow noodles and bee hoon separately.
To serve: Place noodles in bowls, top with prawns, pork ribs, fish cake, bean sprouts, and kang kong. Ladle hot prawn broth over. Garnish with fried shallots. Serve with sambal and lime.
tips: Use fresh prawn heads and shells for the richest broth.
Add pork skin or dried sole fish for extra umami if desired.
recipes.source: Adapted from Rasa Malaysia, The MeatMen, and Singapore hawker stalls.
steps: Peel and devein prawns, reserving heads and shells. Set prawns aside.
In a large pot, heat a little oil and fry prawn heads and shells until fragrant and red. Add garlic and peppercorns, fry briefly.
Add water and pork ribs. Bring to a boil, skim scum, then simmer 1 hour. Add rock sugar and season with salt to taste.
Blanch prawns, fish cake, and kang kong in boiling water. Blanch yellow noodles and bee hoon separately.
To serve: Place noodles in bowls, top with prawns, pork ribs, fish cake, bean sprouts, and kang kong. Ladle hot prawn broth over. Garnish with fried shallots. Serve with sambal and lime.

recipes.name: Chicken Claypot Rice (Claypot Ji Fan)
recipes.description: A classic Cantonese-Singaporean dish: fragrant rice cooked in a claypot with marinated chicken, Chinese sausage, mushrooms, and salted fish. Finished with a savory soy sauce and crispy rice crust.
preparation: Marinate chicken with marinade ingredients for at least 30 minutes.
Drain soaked rice and add to claypot with 2.5 cups water. Bring to a boil, then simmer 10 minutes.
Arrange chicken, mushrooms, sausage, ginger, and salted fish on top. Cover and cook 20–25 minutes on low heat until chicken is cooked and rice is tender.
Mix sauce ingredients and pour over rice. Garnish with spring onions. Serve hot, scraping up crispy rice crust.
tips: Use a heavy claypot for best results.
Add salted fish for authentic flavor, but it can be omitted.
recipes.source: Adapted from The Woks of Life, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore hawker stalls.
steps: Marinate chicken with marinade ingredients for at least 30 minutes.
Drain soaked rice and add to claypot with 2.5 cups water. Bring to a boil, then simmer 10 minutes.
Arrange chicken, mushrooms, sausage, ginger, and salted fish on top. Cover and cook 20–25 minutes on low heat until chicken is cooked and rice is tender.
Mix sauce ingredients and pour over rice. Garnish with spring onions. Serve hot, scraping up crispy rice crust.

recipes.name: Black Chicken Herbal Soup (Wu Ji Tang)
recipes.description: A nourishing Chinese herbal soup made with black chicken (silkie), red dates, goji berries, and a blend of traditional herbs. Tonic, restorative, and deeply flavorful.
preparation: Blanch chicken pieces in boiling water, then drain.
Add all ingredients to a large pot. Bring to a boil, then simmer 2 hours.
Season with salt. Serve hot as a nourishing soup.
tips: Use a mix of Chinese herbs for best results.
Add more goji berries for sweetness.
recipes.source: Adapted from The Woks of Life, Singapore home kitchens, and TCM recipes.
steps: Blanch chicken pieces in boiling water, then drain.
Add all ingredients to a large pot. Bring to a boil, then simmer 2 hours.
Season with salt. Serve hot as a nourishing soup.

recipes.name: Chao Tah Bee Hoon (Crispy Rice Vermicelli Cake)
recipes.description: A Teochew-Singaporean specialty: rice vermicelli pressed and pan-fried until crispy on the outside, soft inside, served with seafood, pork, and vegetables in a savory gravy.
preparation: Press soaked bee hoon into a round cake. Pan-fry in oil until golden and crisp on both sides. Remove and drain.
In a wok, sauté garlic, pork, prawns, and squid. Add vegetables, mushrooms, and stock. Season with sauces and pepper.
Thicken gravy with cornstarch slurry. Pour over crispy bee hoon cake. Serve hot.
tips: Use a nonstick pan for best results.
Add more seafood or vegetables as desired.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Teochew restaurants.
steps: Press soaked bee hoon into a round cake. Pan-fry in oil until golden and crisp on both sides. Remove and drain.
In a wok, sauté garlic, pork, prawns, and squid. Add vegetables, mushrooms, and stock. Season with sauces and pepper.
Thicken gravy with cornstarch slurry. Pour over crispy bee hoon cake. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Suan Pan Zi (Abacus Seeds)
recipes.description: A classic Hakka dish popular in Singapore: chewy yam abacus seeds stir-fried with minced pork, mushrooms, dried shrimp, and black fungus. Symbolizes wealth and reunion.
preparation: Mash steamed yam while hot. Mix with salt and tapioca starch to form a dough. Add water as needed.
Roll into small balls, press center to form abacus shape. Boil in water until they float. Drain and set aside.
Heat oil, sauté garlic, dried shrimp, pork, mushrooms, and fungus. Add abacus seeds, season with sauces and pepper. Stir-fry well. Garnish with spring onions.
tips: Use more yam for softer texture, more starch for chewier seeds.
Add carrots or dried cuttlefish for variation.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore Hakka kitchens.
steps: Mash steamed yam while hot. Mix with salt and tapioca starch to form a dough. Add water as needed.
Roll into small balls, press center to form abacus shape. Boil in water until they float. Drain and set aside.
Heat oil, sauté garlic, dried shrimp, pork, mushrooms, and fungus. Add abacus seeds, season with sauces and pepper. Stir-fry well. Garnish with spring onions.

recipes.name: Salt Baked Chicken (Yim Guk Gai)
recipes.description: A Teochew and Cantonese favorite in Singapore: whole chicken marinated with Chinese herbs, wrapped, and baked in salt for juicy, aromatic meat. Often served at hawker stalls and home feasts.
preparation: Rub chicken with wine, soy sauce, and pepper. Stuff with ginger, spring onions, dang gui, and goji berries. Marinate 1 hour.
Wrap chicken in parchment and foil. Heat salt in a wok, bury chicken in hot salt, cover, and bake 1 hour over low heat.
Remove, rest 10 minutes, carve and serve.
tips: Use parchment and foil to prevent salt from touching chicken directly.
Add more herbs for a stronger aroma.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Singapore Teochew and Cantonese kitchens.
steps: Rub chicken with wine, soy sauce, and pepper. Stuff with ginger, spring onions, dang gui, and goji berries. Marinate 1 hour.
Wrap chicken in parchment and foil. Heat salt in a wok, bury chicken in hot salt, cover, and bake 1 hour over low heat.
Remove, rest 10 minutes, carve and serve.

recipes.name: Roti Prata
recipes.description: A beloved Indian-Singaporean flatbread: crispy outside, soft and chewy inside. Served with curry or sugar, a breakfast and supper staple at mamak stalls.
preparation: Mix flour, salt, sugar, and condensed milk. Add water gradually to form a soft dough. Knead 10 minutes.
Divide into balls, coat with ghee, cover and rest 2 hours.
Flatten and stretch each ball into a thin sheet. Fold and coil, then flatten again.
Fry on a hot griddle with ghee until golden and crisp. Serve hot with curry or sugar.
tips: Rest dough well for maximum stretchiness.
Add condensed milk for a softer, richer prata.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore mamak stalls.
steps: Mix flour, salt, sugar, and condensed milk. Add water gradually to form a soft dough. Knead 10 minutes.
Divide into balls, coat with ghee, cover and rest 2 hours.
Flatten and stretch each ball into a thin sheet. Fold and coil, then flatten again.
Fry on a hot griddle with ghee until golden and crisp. Serve hot with curry or sugar.

recipes.name: Bak Chor Mee (Minced Pork Noodles)
recipes.description: A beloved Teochew noodle dish: springy noodles tossed in vinegar, chili, and lard, topped with minced pork, mushrooms, fish balls, and crispy shallots. Iconic at Singapore hawker stalls.
preparation: Blanch noodles, toss with chili, vinegar, soy, and lard oil.
Blanch pork, liver, and fish balls. Sauté mushrooms with garlic.
Top noodles with pork, liver, mushrooms, fish balls, shallots, and spring onions. Serve hot.
tips: Use fresh mee pok for best texture.
Add crispy pork lard for extra flavor.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore hawker stalls.
steps: Blanch noodles, toss with chili, vinegar, soy, and lard oil.
Blanch pork, liver, and fish balls. Sauté mushrooms with garlic.
Top noodles with pork, liver, mushrooms, fish balls, shallots, and spring onions. Serve hot.

recipes.name: Chwee Kueh (Steamed Rice Cakes with Preserved Radish)
recipes.description: A classic Teochew breakfast: soft, steamed rice cakes topped with savory chye poh (preserved radish) and chili. Popular at hawker breakfast stalls.
preparation: Mix rice flour, cornstarch, salt, oil, and water. Pour into small molds. Steam 20–25 minutes until set.
Fry garlic, add chye poh, soy, and sugar. Cook until fragrant.
Top steamed cakes with chye poh and serve with chili sauce.
tips: Use metal molds for best texture.
Rinse chye poh to reduce saltiness.
recipes.source: Adapted from The MeatMen, Rasa Malaysia, and Singapore breakfast stalls.
steps: Mix rice flour, cornstarch, salt, oil, and water. Pour into small molds. Steam 20–25 minutes until set.
Fry garlic, add chye poh, soy, and sugar. Cook until fragrant.
Top steamed cakes with chye poh and serve with chili sauce.

recipes.name: Penang Laksa (Assam Laksa)
recipes.description: A tangy, spicy noodle soup from Penang, Malaysia, featuring rice noodles in a tamarind-mackerel broth, topped with pineapple, cucumber, mint, and torch ginger.
steps: Boil mackerel in water with lemongrass and galangal until cooked. Remove fish, debone, and flake the flesh. Reserve stock.
Blend spice paste ingredients until smooth. Fry in oil until fragrant.
Add spice paste, tamarind water, daun kesum, salt, and sugar to the stock. Simmer 15 minutes.
Return flaked fish to the broth. Adjust seasoning to taste.
To serve, place noodles in bowls. Ladle hot broth and fish over. Top with pineapple, cucumber, onion, mint, torch ginger, chili, egg, and a drizzle of prawn paste.
tips: Use fresh mackerel for the best flavor, but canned sardines can be substituted.
Daun kesum and torch ginger are traditional but can be omitted if unavailable.
Adjust tamarind and chili for desired tanginess and heat.
recipes.source: Adapted from Penang hawker and home cook recipes.
recipes.origin: Penang Assam Laksa is a signature dish of Penang, Malaysia, and is also enjoyed in Singapore.
